This is a declaration opposing further relief sought in the Plata case.  At page 3, lines 1-9, the declarant gives the number and breakdown of persons released.  This was release was annoucned after the Plata plaintiffs filed a motion for a prisooner reliease order before the three-judge court.
52 early release pursuant to a governor order

150 people released due to early release for medical need, eligible for parole in 2 months, or scheduled release by August 2021 and good behavior.(52 accounted for below)  Other reductions account for rest.

560 early releases in May.  early releases since March of people serving low offenses, over 60 or vulnerable medical conditions; furloughs permitted for 45 days for people who have served at least 40% of time, with less than 2 years left on sentence
Number as of 4.22.20; (As of 4/6/20:  886 had been moved to home release (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b1ZhoHbK3ow&feature=youtu.be))
Article mentions total of 2400 federal furloughs to date. (I substracted those reported on by 4/22). Some law suits are involved in pushing these releases.

More than 1200 people in federal prison released March through August via compassionate release;  another 7500 total via home release for low level offenses.  (Subtracted the 2400 home releases above for count here)
Five of 42 compasssionate release petitions filed for people in CO BOP facilities prevailed in March through August

Total of  approximately 4000 releases (including 3000 who finished setences) between March 1 and April 28, including 64 with murder convictions.

482 approved for early release.  The remaining portion represents overall population decrease from March 31 to May 13.

article describes 1200 reduction.  Just counted 200, becuase of 1000 above.

Population reduced by 650 since March (as of April 19)

Accelerated parole, including possible emphasis on those over 60 with medical conditions, decreased admission from county jails and courts, few technical parole violations being met with incarceration.
Parole Board approved early release of 119 people due to Covid 19.  Should be out by May 31.
50 of 1100, released pursuant to Exec. Order covering people over 60, at medical high risk, within 3 months of release, recently considered for parole (no sex assault, murder convictions eligible)
Less than 30 days to release with a parole plan in place.  Excludes many crimes, including all sex crimes
71 people released altogether from prison system (I subtracted the 11 reported earlier on line above)
Governor released 8 pregnant women with less than 6 months on sentence for non-violent felonies

Inmates who are released early are non-violent offenders who have underlying health conditions, are pregnant or who are at high-risk for the virus. An additional 182 are serving the remainder of their sentence outside of prison under strict conditions.

Describes sentence modification for vulnerable older people (192, including 3 pregnant women); 485 discretionary sentencing credits. This accounts for some the 667 described above.  Older for men is over 65; for women is over 50, as reported in article.
Article doesn't provide specific details

Early parole for 119 people for covid reasons.  DOCS said getting out those over 50 was important, but not clear that is who was released.  Some reduced population due to not accepting new admissions to the system.
Release of pregnant, 60+ yrs old, minimum-security level prisoners close to release date, via parole and the state's Overcrowding Emergency Statute
Commutations and early releases (856 approved, 81 to be released in December)
Commutations for people vulnerable to harm from Covid.  Makes a tiny dent in density reductions for state

Virginia DOCS website lists 231 approved for early release for underlying medical condition and less than a year to serve(the number released on 4.29 (line below) subtracted.  Program and limitations are described (https://vadoc.virginia.gov/media/1506/vadoc-covid19-early-release-plan.pdf)

336 includes 245 releases in VA DOC facilities and 91 releases of inmates state responsible housed in local jails;  NBC source specifies breakdown of releases: a year or less to serve and a record of good behavior, excludes anyone convicted of a Class 1 felony or a violent sex offense. Guidelines put out by prison officials say they’re considering inmates’ medical conditions when making decisions and prioritizing people convicted of non-violent offenses, felony weapons offenses, involuntary manslaughter and voluntary manslaughter

About 70 parolees who were serving short terms for parole-related sanctions have been released. In addition, any pre-trial inmates who did not pose a risk to public safety could be released on a personal recognizance or reduced bond.
Offenders participating in an Alternative Revocation program released under the DOC (65 offenders)
